prompt:
Is the person who wrote this in the wrong in the following situation?

"""
AITA for resenting that my children see their mom as a hero?
My ex wife is a perennial fuck up. She’s been to jail on numerous occasions, had several affairs, lost more jobs than I’ve ever had, and currently lives with her mother. I was a single dad for three years to three children, years where I learned to braid hair so I could care for my daughter. I’ve remarried, and my wife and I provide the children with everything. We pay for their healthcare. We help them with their school work. We sign them up for activities they are interested in and take them to those activities. We pay for those activities. We help them with their school projects. My son is almost 16, and we will buy his car. My eight year old daughter needs braces, and we will pay for them. I ask their mother for no child support because she can’t even support herself. I don’t wish to hurt her. In fact, I’ve forgiven her for who she is and what she’s done. 
Fast forward to tonight: my daughter is entering a pageant. We’ve paid for the dress. We’ve paid the entrance fee. She gets me ask her questions she might be asked at the pageant. One was, “Who is your hero and why?” 
My daughter says, “Do you think I should say, ‘my mom?’”
I said, “ You realize you have family here? We provide for you. We registered you for this pageant. We attended the meeting. You live here full time. We care for you and love you. I know that you get to go to your mom’s every other weekend, and you have no chores there. You eat whatever you like (mom has food stamps), but it’s easy to be a parent two weekends a month. It’s harder to be a parent all the time.” 

I’ve never derogated their mother. I don’t want to cripple their image of her, but it’s frustrating as hell that they see her as this angel and don’t appreciate everything their stepmother and I do for them. 
"""

Is the author in the wrong? Answer A for Yes (the author is in the wrong) and B for No (the author is not in the wrong). Answer nothing else.

The scenario is about a father who is a step-parent now, and his kids see their mom (his ex) as a hero, even though she has a troubled history. The father is frustrated because he and his new wife take care of the kids, providing everything, while the ex has issues like jail time, affairs, and can't support herself. When his daughter asks about choosing her mom as her hero for a pageant, the father responds by pointing out that he and his wife take care of them full-time.

From a parental responsibility standpoint, the father is trying to manage the kids' perception without being negative. He doesn't want to hurt the ex, but he's frustrated. The daughter is 8, so she's young. The father's response could influence her view of both parents. However, he's not directly criticizing the ex mother; he's just highlighting the step-parent's role. 

But does he have a right to be upset? It's natural for kids to sometimes idealize a parent they see less of. The step-parent is doing a lot, but the biological parent might still be seen as special. The father's frustration is valid, but how he addresses it matters. His response is honest but might be harsh for a young child to understand. Is he in the wrong for expressing his feelings, or is it okay to set realistic expectations?

Also, he's not cutting off contact, but he's trying to balance the kids' perception. The key question is whether his response is reasonable or if he overstepped. The answer depends on whether his words were meant to undermine the mother or just to help the daughter understand the situation. He says he doesn't want to derogate her, so maybe he's in a tough spot here. 

In summary, the father's intentions are good, but his method might be questionable. However, the core issue is about differing parental roles and the child's perception. The answer likely depends on cultural or social norms around co-parenting and step-parent dynamics. I think the answer is B (No) because he's trying to manage the situation without being negative, but he's frustrated and wants the kids to appreciate his efforts. However, it's a close call.
